121.66.text:

151.50.text: been the early formations of star.

159.68.text: with this special type of alcohol.

162.57.text:
This cloud be proof of living organisms traveling

190.34.text:
is a huge gathering of swirling gas and space

269.87.text:
“Gliese [“Glee-zuh”] 581g [“581-gee”]:
The Gliese star system is located 120 trillion

277.42.text:
miles away from Earth, and its existence has
captured the attention of researchers for

284.58.text:
That’s because out of all of the places

289.11.text:
by man, Gliese 581g is the most likely for

296.64.text:
As such, it is also the most likely place

302.80.text:

307.50.text:
Well, 100 percent – at least according to
Dr. Steven Vogt [“Vote”], the person responsible

317.45.text:
The rocky planet is thought to contain a working
atmosphere that has water, though scientists

322.54.text:
aren’t sure exactly what this supposed atmosphere

326.91.text:
Gliese 581g is roughly twice the size of Earth
and has double the amount of gravity.

333.76.text:
A full year on this planet is over in only
37 days.

338.26.text:
It does sound pretty inhabitable [“in-hab-bit-tah-ble”]
at first.

341.10.text:
However, the planet also has a dangerous side
as well.

346.65.text: You see, Gliese 581g does not spin.

350.88.text:
Instead, one half of the planet constantly
bakes under the hot sun while a colder side

358.19.text:
So basically one side of the planet is hot
enough to melt you instantly, and the other

363.52.text:
half is cold enough to freeze you to death
in less than a second.

368.01.text:
Only a very tiny strip of land towards the
center of the planet is the right temperature

372.94.text:
for mankind to survive in – and that’s
probably where the aliens are already living,

380.26.text:
Exactly what types of aliens live there is
unknown, but we have been beaming radio signals

385.36.text:
there since 1995 in an effort to communicate
with them.

389.74.text:
There’s been no response so far, so either
the alien life is not very technologically-advanced,

395.08.text: or they are just playing hard to get.

398.91.text:
The prospect of active alien life is the scariest

405.38.text:
Even though scientists have some strong theories,

411.35.text:
It could one day become the first site of

422.63.text:

“Gravitational Lensing” [“Grav-vit-tay-shun-nal”
“Len-sing”]: Objects on Earth always appear

433.78.text:
one in front of the other, but in space, nothing
is as it seems.

439.49.text:
“Gravitational lensing” is what happens
when an object is so large that it changes

444.64.text: the properties of space and time.

447.53.text:
Basically, the object is able to bend light
to create all sorts of crazy-looking effects.

454.83.text:
Sometimes this can cause a mirror image of
an object to form when nothing is there, sometimes

459.33.text:
this can cause a nearby object to look smaller
when it is actually much larger, and sometimes

465.12.text:
the bent light can be used even be used to
find stuff in space that would otherwise be

471.30.text:
In the most extreme cases, however, it can
even let you see through objects that are

477.56.text: Take this picture of two planets for example.

480.36.text: See that little bright star in the middle?

482.31.text:
It’s actually behind the larger planet,
not in front – and no, the larger planet

489.58.text:
That’s the gravitational lensing effect
in action.

495.56.text:
Well, let’s just say that when you are traveling
through space, “objects in the mirror can

503.46.text:
Space’s ability to bend light also applies
to soundwaves as well.

508.93.text:
One day scientists hope to master the gravitational

514.15.text:
signals faster and deeper into space than
ever before.

518.83.text:
If all goes well, the gravitational lensing
effect will let us one day instantly talk

523.47.text:
to alien spacecraft that are way too far away

531.20.text:

583.45.text:

598.37.text:

“Faces of Mars”: You’ve heard of the

778.62.text:

996.44.text:

1142.74.text:

1249.49.text:
Do you think this photograph is simply the

1360.76.text: at the far ends of our universe.

Because we’ve been watching it eat entire

1578.66.text:
one isn’t extremely scary or anything, but

About 12 billion light-years away from you

What exactly will become of this giant floating
cloud of water remains to be seen.

1633.99.text:
Some scientists expect that it will eventually
grow so large that it will be ejected out

1638.37.text: of the galaxy and roam the stars on its own.

1642.53.text:
Eventually it may even come into contact with
another planet and form life.

1647.12.text:
Others expect that the floating mass will
begin to form living one-celled organisms

1650.85.text:
on its own that may eventually be passed onto
whatever planet the water comes into contact

1656.90.text:
It really all depends on if the planet contains
an atmosphere that can host water-based life

1662.99.text:
Who knows, perhaps this was even how life
on planet Earth was formed.

1667.64.text:
Maybe all of the water that makes up our oceans
originally started out as a cluster of water

1672.78.text: vapor from a strange and special black hole.

1676.06.text:
So as you can see, black holes aren’t always
that bad.

1679.98.text: You may have even came from one.
